caption:
This image portrays a forest scene heavily influenced by logging activity. In the foreground, a chaotic pile of cut tree trunks and timber debris dominates the view, laying haphazard over one another. These logs vary in size and condition, with some having jagged edges and splintered ends that suggest recent and perhaps hasty cutting. The moist, darkened wood surface and the presence of bark remnants suggest that the logging occurred not long before the picture was taken.

The middle ground consists of tall, dense coniferous trees, standing straight and providing a stark contrast to the chaotic timber piles below. The trees look lush, with dark green foliage thickly covering the area, indicating that this section of the forest remains largely untouched.

In the background, the forest continues with similar dense trees, but it also hints at a rising terrain or mountainous area. The trees appear slightly shrouded by mist or low cloud, lending a gloomy and somewhat mysterious ambience to the atmosphere. The lighting in the image is subdued, suggesting an overcast day and enhancing the feeling of dampness and the chill typically associated with such forest environments.

The overall composition of the photograph serves as a poignant view on the impact of human activities such as logging on natural landscapes, highlighting the contrast between the disturbed and undisturbed parts of the forest.
title: Douglas fir and hemlock logs on the canyon river drainage system in olympic national timberland, Washington.  Near Olympic National Park
